Literature Review: The study of DNA fragility and repair mechanisms has been a cornerstone in understanding the molecular basis of cancer and other genetic disorders. This literature review delves into the intricacies of endogenous DNA damage, the base excision repair (BER) pathway, and alternative repair strategies for unusual DNA lesions, as highlighted in the autobiographical reflections of a researcher with a Swedish background. Endogenous DNA damage, including the loss of purine bases and cytosine deamination, has been identified as a significant source of mutations that can lead to cancer (Lindahl, 1993). The BER pathway plays a crucial role in correcting these damages, involving a series of enzymes that recognize and remove the damaged bases, followed by the insertion of the correct nucleotides (Krokan & Bjørås, 2013). DNA glycosylases, the enzymes that initiate the BER pathway by recognizing and excising damaged bases, have been extensively studied for their specificity and efficiency in repairing various types of DNA lesions (David et al., 2007). The complexity of DNA repair mechanisms is further highlighted by the existence of alternative repair strategies for lesions that are not efficiently processed by the BER pathway. For instance, the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway can remove bulky DNA lesions, while the mismatch repair (MMR) system corrects base-base mismatches and insertion-deletion loops (Friedberg et al., 2006). The interplay between these repair pathways ensures the maintenance of genomic integrity, but their failure can lead to the accumulation of mutations and the development of cancer (Hoeijmakers, 2001). The autobiographical account provides a unique perspective on the evolution of DNA repair research, emphasizing the importance of understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying DNA damage and repair. This narrative not only sheds light on the scientific journey of a researcher but also underscores the critical role of DNA repair mechanisms in preventing cancer and maintaining cellular homeostasis. The insights gained from studying DNA fragility and repair have profound implications for cancer therapy, as targeting DNA repair pathways can enhance the efficacy of chemotherapy and radiation therapy (Lord & Ashworth, 2012). Furthermore, the identification of genetic polymorphisms in DNA repair genes has opened new avenues for personalized medicine, allowing for the prediction of individual susceptibility to cancer and the optimization of therapeutic strategies (Goode et al., 2002). In conclusion, the study of DNA fragility and repair mechanisms is essential for understanding the molecular basis of cancer and developing effective therapeutic strategies. The autobiographical reflections provide a compelling narrative that highlights the significance of DNA repair research in advancing our knowledge of cancer biology and improving patient outcomes.
